sentence: Fueled by strong technical support and expectations for the Federal Open Market Committee to soothe worries over rapid rate hikes at the conclusion of tomorrow's meeting, stocks erased Monday's losses with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up more than 100 points at the close and snapping a two day losing streak.
Blue chips outperformed with gains in nearly every component stock.
S&P 500 sectors were all mostly higher as well with the exception of utility and energy stocks, the former despite lower Treasury yields, and the latter on lingering supply issues for oil.
Stocks were defensive at Tuesday's open with investors spooked by worries of a Greek debt default that resulted in widespread selling across Europe.
May housing market data amplified the negative tone with construction on new homes dropping 11% from April.

By the European close, Wall Street had trimmed Monday's losses thanks to solid technical support at 17,700 in the Dow and 2070 in the S&P 500, as well as expectations that while the FOMC will signal their intention to raise rates this year, they will refrain from rapid and unexpected moves that could rattle financial markets.
The FOMC meeting concludes at 2:00ET Wednesday with a statement immediately following and press conference at 2:30ET.
There is no economic data scheduled.

Here's where the markets stood at the close:

(+) OPTT (+22.42%) Gets final permit for deployment southeast of New York City Harbor

(-) AAVL (-56.15%) Concerns about the strength of the results of the firm's AVA-101 drug candidate for macular degeneration

(-) TAHO (-9.14%) Goldcorp ( GG ) will sell its 25.6% interest in Tahoe Resources through a secondary offering
